lesson.title: Understanding Data
lesson.summary: Understand the most common data types. Understand the various sources of data.

atoms.title: overview
atoms.text:
# Overview

The course will take you through the many techniques you will need to clean up and blend your data. You will meet Maureen from Alteryx and she'll take you through the four skillsets that you'll need to prepare your datasets:

1. Understanding different data types
 - Explore the differences between strings, integers, doubles, and bytes
2. Dealing with dirty and missing data as well as outliers
 - Explore deduping, string parsing and replacements, and imputation
3. Manipulating rows and columns of data
 - Explore transposing, aggregation, and cross tabulation
4. Blend data through joins and unions
 - Explore fuzzy matching and spatial blending to help with spatial analysis

# Project

Feel free to skip around the course if you're already familiar with some of these topics already. You do not have to go through every video in this course if you're already familiar with these data cleanup techniques.

To help you gauge what data cleaning techniques you need for the project, the project will focus on joins, unions, aggregation, and string manipulations. If you're already familiar with these techniques, feel free to skip ahead and start working on [the project](https://classroom.udacity.com/nanodegrees/nd008t-ent/parts/ec4b7a7b-1694-4c0c-bfed-224d0733896c/modules/13c582f8-2d91-4eb2-ab81-62f6bdd7ff53/lessons/927c5734-88eb-44fc-9410-35a55562564a/concepts/07cee546-9a15-406f-b161-74308c4e0c42).

atoms.title: Intro
atoms.instructor_notes:
You will learn...

  • The most common sources of data
  • The different ways data are structured and why it matters

    You will be able to...

  • Input a dataset into Alteryx
  • Recognize structural issues
  • Optimize the field types to fit the data

atoms.title: before
atoms.text:
#### Before You Get Started

Make sure you have the latest version of Alteryx installed on your computer. You can download the latest version of [Alteryx here](http://www.alteryx.com/download).

The tools and features you will learn in this course should be compatible with at least version 10.6.

atoms.title: Types of Data
atoms.text:
Structured Data

Structured data are data with a high degree of organization. They are typically organized into columns and rows like in a spreadsheet. Sometimes columns are also called fields and rows are referred to as records and these terms may end up being used interchangeably throughout the course. Each column represents a variable and each row represents a record of data. Structured data is often stored in databases or files such as spreadsheets and it is usually easily accessible and most importantly, it’s easy to use.

Unstructured Data

Unstructured data can have no structure to it at all. Since the data isn’t organized into a typical columns and rows format, it can be time-consuming to work with as you have to pull what you want out of it. Some examples of this type of data are a resume, a tweet or a contract document.

Semistructured Data

Semi-structured data is data that has some structure to it but still requires some work to put it into a structured format of columns and rows. This could be a computer system log file that requires parsing and manipulating to put into a format that makes the data easier to analyze.

atoms.title: Classifying Data
atoms.text: Here are a few examples of data.  Based on what you’ve learned so far, classify these data as either structured, semi-structured or unstructured.

question.prompt: What type of data is this?

atoms.text:
# Input a File in Alteryx

The video below shows how to upload an Excel file in Alteryx. You can find the file at the bottom of the page. Also, below is a snap shot of the data so you have an idea of what it looks like during the demonstration.

This image is a screenshot of the latest version of the Filter tool. All the functionality is the same. The UI is slightly updated. You can also see if you select the custom filter option it uses the new fx and X icons to reference the functions and variables respectively just like the new formula tool.

atoms.title: Skills Reviewed
atoms.text:
### Skills Reviewed 
* Input data: Use input tool, select file (**'Cust WTransaction'**), and select tab to input data into Alteryx
* Filter: Use filter tool to limit the data based on select criteria.

### Alteryx Sample Data
The sample data for Alteryx is typically found with the following path: C:\Program Files\Alteryx\Samples\SampleData\. You can also find the data file below. This file has also been updated since the video was made from xls to xlsx.

atoms.title: Note
atoms.text:
Which customer segment makes up the most of our Denver customers?

Skills Reviewed

* Summarize data: Use [Summarize](https://help.alteryx.com/current/Summarize.htm?tocpath=Tools%257CTool%2520Categories%257CTransform%257C_____5) tool, select field, select group by and then select the operation to use to summarize the data. * Sort: Use [Sort](https://help.alteryx.com/current/Sort.htm?tocpath=Tools%257CTool%2520Categories%257CPreparation%257C_____17) tool and select a field to sort the data.

atoms.title: Alteryx Exercise
atoms.text:
# Alteryx Exercise

Now’s your opportunity to explore this same data further. Download the **cust_wTransactions.xls** file found at the bottom of the page. Use Alteryx to answer the following questions:

How many stores have more than 300 customers?

**Notes:** Each customer has been assigned a store that they shop at.

question.prompt: How many stores have more than 300 customers?
Which city has the most customers?

atoms.title: Steps
atoms.text:
Steps to Complete Exercise

Step 1:
Use an input tool to input the data from 'cust_wTransactions.xls'
Step 2:
Use a summarize tool to create a dataset with the number of customers per store.
Step 3:
Use a filter tool to limit the dataset to stores with 300+ customers. See the video below for a full walk through of how to arrive at the solution.

### Note on Databases

You will not be required to connect to or analyze data from a database in this course. If this is something you need to do for your job, we encourage you to look at the database connection documentation on the [Alteryx website](https://help.alteryx.com/current/ManageInDBConnections.htm).

atoms.title: sources of data web scraping example
atoms.instructor_notes: Link to magazine article that lists top doctors in the Denver Metro area

atoms.title: Sources of Data - Web Scraping Example 2
API's
atoms.text:
Web-based Sources - APIs

Another way of pulling data from a web based source is to access an API. To learn a little more about APIs, you can read [this article](http://schoolofdata.org/2013/11/18/web-apis-for-non-programmers/) If you want to learn how to use APIs in Alteryx, read [this blog post](http://community.alteryx.com/t5/Engine-Works-Blog/REST-API-In-5-Minutes-No-Coding/ba-p/8137 ) on how to pull data from the Quandl API. It walks you through the process in Alteryx.

atoms.title: Web scraping
atoms.text:
For your Alteryx exercise, you are going to scrape a page on the Alteryx site containing the list of Alteryx ACEs. The ACE program highlights the most influential and supportive experts of Alteryx Analytics. Scrape the page http://www.alteryx.com/ace-program and output the results to a CSV file with no delimiter (Delimiter is \0) and where the first row does not contain field names. As we saw in the earlier example, we’ve found that after web scraping content from a web page a lot of parsing will be required for it to be formatted into usable content. We won’t be covering this kind of parsing in the course, however, there are lots of training resources on parsing found in this link: http://www.alteryx.com/product-training

Steps to Complete

**Step 1:** Start with a text input tool, enter the URL of the page and URL as the field name. (You will need to remove the http:// from the URL name) **Step 2:** Then we connect the download tool and add a browse tool. Run the workflow to see the results in the DownloadData cell. This cell contains the entire web page. **Step 3:** To output this to a CSV file, connect the Select tool first to remove the two extraneous fields that do not contain the data from the web page: URL and DownloadHeaders. **Step 4:** Use the Output data tool, change the file format to CSV, enter '\0' in the Delimiter option to denote no delimiter and make sure that the option denoting first row contains field names is deselected. Run the workflow. See the video in the next section for a full walk through of how to arrive at the solution.
## Note: The page: http://www.alteryx.com/ace-program has changed since this excersize was written. The results will differ from the screenshot below.

atoms.title: hint
atoms.text:
#### Result

If you do this correctly, the text that you download from the Alteryx site should look like this:

atoms.title: Solution
atoms.text:
Step 1:
Start with a text input tool, enter the URL of the page and URL as the field name.
Step 2:
Then we connect the download tool and add a browse tool. Run the workflow to see the results in the DownloadData cell. This cell contains the entire web page.
Step 3:
To output this to a CSV file, connect the Select tool first to remove the two extraneous fields that do not contain the data from the web page: URL and DownloadHeaders.
Step 4:
Use the Output data tool, change the file format to CSV, enter '\0' in the Delimiter option to denote no delimiter and make sure that the option denoting first row contains field names is deselected. Run the workflow. See the video below for a full walk through of how to arrive at the solution.

atoms.title: sources of data web scraping exercise
Common Data Types
atoms.text:
Strings
Strings are any combination of characters, alpha-numeric including symbols. Some examples can be an address field, a state code, an open-ended survey response or a product description.
Numeric
Numeric data are numbers which can be whole numbers such as integers or numbers with decimal places. Some examples are sales in dollars, population in a trade area around a store or the age of a person.
Date/Time
Date/time data can contain a specific date or a combination of both date and time. This data can be really handy for calculating the number of minutes between a caller reporting a problem and its resolution.
Boolean
The Boolean type is sometimes also called a Logical type and is a conditional flag representing either true or false.
Special Objects
Special objects which can be objects such as images, maps, report objects, and sound files to name a few examples.

atoms.title: Data Types Quiz
atoms.text:
Look at the dataset below. Identify the appropriate data type that fits with these fields:

<li>Employee <li>Address<li>Distance<li>Telecommuter

answers.text: special character, string, date/time, special character

atoms.title: Skills
atoms.text:
Skills Reviewed

  • Create new variable: Use formula tool to create a field based on one of the existing field.
  • Change data type : Use select tool to change the data type of one or more variables.
  • Automate data type selection: Use Autofield tool to have the data type of each field be set automatically to best fit the data.

question.prompt: Now it’s your turn to practice what you’ve learned with data types.  Using the file **transactions.xml** at the bottom of the page, what are the total sales for Order 10080?

concepts.title: Data Types Exercise in Alteryx Solution

atoms.title: Steps
atoms.text:
Step 1:
Use an input tool to input the data from 'transactions.xml' Step 2:
Use a select tool to change the Sales field to a numeric format. Step 3:
Use a summarize tool and group by order ID to sum the sales field. Step 4:
Use a filter tool to only see the data for order 10080. Result:
Total sales for order 10080 was $637.04. See the video below for a full walk through of how to arrive at the solution.
